scenario: My uncle has a terminal illness. When he was 60 he completed an Enduring Power Of Attorney, appointing me as the attorney. He didn't appoint his immediate family as he regarded them as irresponsible financially. Now his mental capacity has deteriorated and it is time to use it.
question: Who do I need to tell that I intend to register the EPA?
answers: tell the donor, their family members and other attorneys
• Tell the donor, their family members and other attorneys you intend to register the EPA.

You must tell the first 3 eligible family members from the following list. If there’s no family member in a particular category, move on to the next one. You must try to tell the family members in this order:
• donor’s children (including adopted children but not including stepchildren)
• donor’s brothers and sisters (including half-brothers and half-sisters)
• widow or widower or surviving civil partner of the donor’s child
• donor’s nephews and nieces (children of the donor’s full brothers and sisters)
• donor’s nephews and nieces (children of the donor’s half-brothers and half-sisters)
• donor’s aunts and uncles (full brothers or sisters of a parent of the donor)
• donor’s first cousins (children of the donor’s aunts and uncles who are full brothers and sisters of a parent of the donor)
You must tell all the people in a category if you tell one of them, eg if 1 of the 3 relatives you’re telling is a grandchild and the donor has 15 other grandchildren, you must tell all 16 of them.
If you’re a family member as well as an attorney, you count as one of the people to be told. You’ll still have to tell other people in your category.

scenario: My child has recently diagnosed with dyslexia and I've been told that there are different tools that can help in daily life, these all seem quite expensive online so i am unsure if we can afford them.
question: Is there any funding or support available for children with dyslexia? what are they?
answers: an education, health and care (ehc) plan
evidences: If you think your child may have special educational needs, contact the SEN co-ordinator, or ‘SENCO’ in your child’s school or nursery.
Your child may be eligible for:
• SEN support - support given in school, like speech therapy
• an education, health and care (EHC) plan - a plan of care for children and young people aged up to 25 who have more complex needs
SEN support for children under 5 includes:
• making reasonable adjustments for disabled children, like providing aids like tactile signs
An education, health and care (EHC) plan is for children and young people aged up to 25 who need more support than is available through special educational needs support.
EHC plans identify educational, health and social needs and set out the additional support to meet those needs.

scenario: My child is 5 years old and starting school this year, he is physically well however I feel as though my child is developing slower than other children are at the same age which i am concerned about.
question: Is my child able to be assessed for extra learning support in school?
evidences: Your child may be eligible for:
• an education, health and care (EHC) plan - a plan of care for children and young people aged up to 25 who have more complex needs
Your child may need an education, health and care (EHC) plan if they need more support than their school provides.
Talk to the teacher or the SEN co-ordinator (SENCO) if you think your child needs:
• a special learning programme
• extra help from a teacher or assistant
• to work in a smaller group
• observation in class or at break
• help taking part in class activities
• extra encouragement in their learning, for example to ask questions or to try something they find difficult

scenario: I run a small, independent charity which attempts to help people struggling with their vet costs. I have several people who pay monthly by direct debit and also receive some one off donations.
question: Am I eligible for Gift Aid?
answers: You must be recognised as a charity or CASC for tax purposes.
• have paid at least as much in Income Tax or Capital Gains Tax in that tax year as you want to claim in Gift Aid
• make a Gift Aid declaration that gives you permission to claim it
• that are a payment for goods or services or made because your charity or CASC bought goods and services
• where the donor gets a ‘benefit’ over a certain limit
• from charity cards or of vouchers, for example Charities Aid Foundation (CAF) vouchers
evidences: You can claim back 25p every time an individual donates £1 to your charity or community amateur sports club (CASC). This is called Gift Aid.
You must be recognised as a charity or CASC for tax purposes.
The donor must:
• have paid at least as much in Income Tax or Capital Gains Tax in that tax year as you want to claim in Gift Aid
• make a Gift Aid declaration that gives you permission to claim it
You can claim Gift Aid on donations from individuals. The donor must:
• have paid the same amount or more in Income Tax or Capital Gains Tax in that tax year
You cannot claim on donations:
• made through Payroll Giving
• that are a payment for goods or services or made because your charity or CASC bought goods and services
• where the donor gets a ‘benefit’ over a certain limit
• of shares
• from charity cards or of vouchers, for example Charities Aid Foundation (CAF) vouchers

If you don't pass your full moped or motorcycle test within 2 years, you have to stop riding. You can be fined up to £1,000. You can get up to 6 penalty points. scenario: My father was unfairly suspended but was still in the  ADI register and won the case through an appeal . He suffered loss of income and depression during the trial.
question: Can he be compensated?
evidences: You can claim compensation if you’ve been suspended but are not then taken off the register.
You can get compensation if your approved driving instructor (ADI) registration was suspended, but you were not taken off the ADI register.
This includes cases where:
• you win an appeal against the decision to take you off the register
You can claim compensation for income and non-income losses as a result of being suspended.
You can also claim for the cost of preparing your compensation application.
‘Income losses’ are what you’d have got from giving driving lessons during the time you were suspended.
Examples of non-income losses include:
• any reasonable costs you needed to pay to prepare your compensation application
• the interest on a loan you had to take out as a result of the suspension
• the value of any damage that the suspension caused to your driving school business if you run one

scenario: I own and operate an electronics company in Southern England, which currently has 140 employees. As part of our expansion into the EU, about 5 of our employees will need to be seconded to our office in France for a 6 month period. Their current principal statements make no mention of overseas employment.
question: If I make changes to their principal statements, how soon do I need to notify the affected workers?
answers: within one month of making the change
evidences: The written statement is made up of:
• the main document (known as a ‘principal statement’)
Employers must tell employees or workers about any changes to the written statement. They must do this within one month of making the change.
The principal statement must include at least:
• where an employee or worker will be working and whether they might have to relocate
If an employee or worker has to work outside the UK for more than a month, the principal statement must also include:
• how long they’ll be abroad

scenario: I am an employee and shop steward (USDAW) at a carpet retailer in the Midlands. Owing to the effect of COVID-19 on the retail trade my employer has announced 25 redundancies, without bothering to run a full consultation either with our union or with the employees as a whole.
question: Is it ok for the company not holding a consultation?
evidences: If you do not consult employees in a redundancy situation, any redundancies you make will almost certainly be unfair and you could be taken to an employment tribunal.
You must follow ‘collective consultation’ rules if you’re making 20 or more employees redundant within any 90-day period at a single establishment.
Consultation does not have to end in agreement, but it must be carried out with a view to reaching it, including ways of avoiding or reducing the redundancies.

scenario: I am 65 years old. I am looking to buy grab rails, which I will have the product installed at my home.

• grab rails

scenario: My grandfather is 65 years old and physically disabled . He owns a flat and would like to install an easily accessible bath and new lighting system. For him to get a reduced VAT on the items he wishes to buy.
question: What does he need to do to be qualify for the reduced rate?
answers: confirm to your supplier in writing that you meet these conditions
evidences: Your supplier should know about the reduced rate and apply it. You qualify if:
• you’re over 60 when the product is supplied or installed
• the product is installed - you do not get the reduced rate if you just buy it
• the product is for a private home, for example your own home or one shared with friends or relatives (a residential care home does not qualify)

You’ll need to confirm to your supplier in writing that you meet these conditions. They may give you a form, or you can sign your own declaration. Ask a relative, partner or other responsible person if you’re not able to fill it in yourself.

scenario: I am a director at the company I work at. Since I have fallen into some financial trouble after my divorce and my house catching on fire I requested a loan from my company. The board agreed and lent me £25000. I have been paying interest on this loan but at a lower rate then the official one since I am still struggling to get on my feet.
question: Do we note the payments below the official rate in a normal way?
evidences: Your personal and company tax responsibilities depend on how the loan is settled. You also need to check if you have extra tax responsibilities if:
• the loan was more than £10,000 (£5,000 in 2013-14)
• you paid your company interest on the loan below the official rate
If you’re a shareholder and director, your company must:
• record interest you pay below the official rate as company income
• treat the discounted interest as a ‘benefit in kind’
You must report the interest on a personal Self Assessment tax return. You may have to pay tax on the difference between the official rate and the rate you paid.

answers: • living in the UK or a country that pays bereavement benefits
evidences: You may be able to get Bereavement Support Payment (BSP) if your husband, wife or civil partner died in the last 21 months.
You must claim within 3 months of your partner’s death to get the full amount. You can claim up to 21 months after their death but you’ll get fewer monthly payments.
You could be eligible if your partner either:
• paid National Insurance contributions for at least 25 weeks in one tax year since 6 April 1975
• died because of an accident at work or a disease caused by work
When they died you must have been:
• under State Pension age
• living in the UK or a country that pays bereavement benefits

CASCs must be open to people of all ethnicities, nationalities, sexual orientations, religions or beliefs, sexes, ages and ability - except when a certain level of physical ability is needed to take part in a sport.
• not make a profit, unless this is reinvested in the club and spent only on promoting participation and providing facilities for eligible sports
• not pay more than £10,000 in total to all players in a year (before 1 April 2015 CASCs couldn’t pay players at all)

scenario: I have a small business manufacturing and selling high quality cured meats in Northern Ireland. We sell all around the world, including to the EU.
question: What prefix do I need to put in front of my VAT number for EU sales?
evidences: When you register, you’ll be sent a VAT registration certificate. This confirms:
• your VAT number
If you’re a VAT-registered business, you need to tell HMRC if any of the following apply:
• your goods are located in Northern Ireland at the time of sale
• you sell or move goods from Northern Ireland to an EU country
When you are trading with the EU and sell goods in Northern Ireland, you’ll need to:

• put an ‘XI’ prefix in front of your VAT number when communicating with an EU customer or supplier (your invoices will show XI in front of your VAT number - for example, XI 123456789 - instead of GB)

scenario: I have a business renting out construction tools like cement mixers and whacker plates. I have just registered for VAT as my turnover has now gone over the £85,000 threshold.
question: How far can I backdate claims for VAT on tools I have purchased previously?
answers: • 4 years for goods you still have, or that were used to make other goods you still have
evidences: You must register your business for VAT with HM Revenue and Customs (HMRC) if its VAT taxable turnover is more than £85,000.
There’s a time limit for backdating claims for VAT paid before registration. From your date of registration the time limit is:
• 4 years for goods you still have, or that were used to make other goods you still have
• 6 months for services

You can only reclaim VAT on purchases for the business now registered for VAT. They must relate to your ‘business purpose’. This means they must relate to VAT taxable goods or services that you supply.

scenario: I live in the UK and wish to purchase an item worth approximately £100 from an overseas (non-UK) supplier, with the purchase transaction taking place online. The item in question is for personal use, and is not intended as a gift.
question: Is VAT payable on this purchase, either at point of sale or on delivery?
answers: the seller will have included vat in the total you paid
evidences: Anything posted or couriered to you from another country goes through customs to check it is not banned or restricted and you pay the right tax and ‘duty’ on it.
This includes anything new or used that you:
• buy online
• buy abroad and send back to the UK
Before receiving your goods, you may have to pay VAT, Customs Duty or Excise Duty if they were sent to:
• Great Britain (England, Wales and Scotland) from outside the UK
• Northern Ireland from countries outside the UK and the European Union (EU)
VAT is charged on all goods (except for gifts worth £39 or less) sent from:
• outside the UK to Great Britain
• outside the UK and the EU to Northern Ireland
VAT is not charged on goods that are gifts worth £39 or less.
Goods worth £135 or less in total
If you bought the goods yourself and they are not excise goods, the seller will have included VAT in the total you paid.

scenario: I am 19 and rent a bedsit in a multiple tenancy building in the North of the UK. I am concerned that there is not an adequate provision in the case of fire.
question: I need to know the fire safety measures that my landlord is taking.. what are they?
answers: provide a smoke alarm on each storey and a carbon monoxide alarm in any room with a solid fuel burning appliance
check you have access to escape routes at all times
make sure the furniture and furnishings they supply are fire safe
• provide fire alarms and extinguishers if the property is a large house in multiple occupation (HMO)

• follow safety regulations
• provide a smoke alarm on each storey and a carbon monoxide alarm in any room with a solid fuel burning appliance (for example a coal fire or wood burning stove)
• check you have access to escape routes at all times
• make sure the furniture and furnishings they supply are fire safe
• provide fire alarms and extinguishers if the property is a large house in multiple occupation (HMO)

scenario: I live in a rented property in England which needs repairs. The heating system is not working and the water pipes are leaking. The bathroom sink and taps are faulty and damaged.
question: Who should I contact to do the repairs?
answers: the environmental health department at your local council
housing department at your local council
If your house is not fit to live in
evidences: Your landlord is always responsible for repairs to:
• basins, sinks, baths and other sanitary fittings including pipes and drains
• heating and hot water
If your property needs repairs
Contact your landlord if you think repairs are needed. Do this straight away for faults that could damage health, for example faulty electrical wiring.
If repairs are not done
Contact the environmental health department at your local council for help. They must take action if they think the problems could harm you or cause a nuisance to others.
If your house is not fit to live in

If you think your home’s unsafe, contact housing department at your local council. They’ll do a Housing Health and Safety Rating System (HHSRS) assessment and must take action if they think your home has serious health and safety hazards.

answers: • travelled to the UK through a ‘safe third country’
• have a connection to a safe third country where you could claim asylum
evidences: To be eligible you must have left your country and be unable to go back because you fear persecution.
To stay in the UK as a refugee you must be unable to live safely in any part of your own country because you fear persecution there.
This persecution must be because of:
• your political opinion
Your claim might not be considered if you:
• are from an EU country
• travelled to the UK through a ‘safe third country’
• have a connection to a safe third country where you could claim asylum

question: What happens if my case cannot be considered?
answers: sent to a safe country that will consider your asylum claim
considered in the uk and given to a caseworker
If the Home Office cannot place you in another safe country, your case will be considered in the UK and given to a caseworker.

scenario: I'm 63 and I had a car accident 1 year ago while a was driving a lorry for my company on the A1. evidences: Some benefits you might get are:
• Universal Credit
• Personal Independence Payment (PIP) or Disability Living Allowance (DLA)
• Attendance Allowance
• ‘new style’ Employment and Support Allowance (ESA)

• Industrial Injuries Benefit if you’re disabled as a result of work

You may be able to get ‘new style’ Employment and Support Allowance (ESA) if you cannot work because of illness or disability.
You may be entitled to get Industrial Injuries Benefit if you’re disabled as a result of:

scenario: My family and I are private tenants and have been for over five years in the same place. My landlord has just increased our rent out of the blue and we cannot afford the new rate. The fixed-term tenancy agreement has two years remaining.
question: Is it acceptable for the landlord to have done this arbitrarily?
evidences: For a fixed-term tenancy (running for a set period) your landlord can only increase the rent if you agree. If you do not agree, the rent can only be increased when the fixed term ends.

The tenancy is fixed-term. The fixed-term tenancy runs for a set period. The landlord can only increase the rent if you agree.
There is a fixed term for the rent. The rent can only be increased when the fixed term ends. If you do not agree, the rent cannot be increased before the fixed term ends.

scenario: I am a junior office worker in a large law firm and have been here for eighteen months.
